physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington c/o Miss Winifred Ellerman, 1 South Audley Street, London, W.1, England. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I enclose you cheque for our half yearly royalties from Houghton Mifflin. They are getting very slim, for, as you know, we are letting the editions run out, so that there will be less and less from this source until finally there is none at all. The bookkeeping is as follows: By sales 24 Imagist Poets, 1915 .43 ½ $10.44 20 " " 1916 .43 ½ 8.70 24 " " 1917 .43 ½ 10.44 $29.58 One-sixth of $29.58 is $4.93

Now as to your poems, I have already placed "The Islands" in the "North American Review." The shorter one I Have not been able to place yet, but I hope to before long. I shall be in New York the last week in October and the first week in November lecturing at Columbia University, and while I am there I can run round and see editors, and I hope to be able to get some one to take this poem of yours.

Now I want to ask you an interesting question: Was Winifred Ellerman hurt by my letter to her about her book "Development"? She seems a very queer, uncertain child and one upon whose toes one is always treading unconsciously. She sent me the book and asked my opinion on it, and I wrote her exactly what my opinion was, some of it favourable, some of it more moderate in tone. I do not really think the book was ready for publication, but I told her as she was publishing it not to worry about that. As I think she will probably have shown you my letter, I will not go at all into the details of what I said, but certainly I did not couch it in a way to hurt any one’s feelings, and equally certainly, when one is asked for a criticism, one should not be huffed when it is given.

I do not understand the girl nor her attitude toward her art. If she is the serious artist I suppose, she would be willing to accept criticism even if she did not want to follow it. There is no necessity whatever for any one to follow criticism, but one should not be annoyed at receiving it. Does she think she is the genius of the world who can arrive at success spontaneously, as it were? I hope I have not hurt her feelings for I like the girl from her letters, and value her youthful and exuberant attitude toward poetry, but she seems inclined to squabble with people rather.

What I am really afraid of is that she will think that Ferris Greenslet’s remarks about her book came from me. As a matter of fact, I gave Ferris Greenslet no opinion whatever about the book before he read it, and I had no idea what he had written to her until after he wrote it. It was rather funny, therefore, that our opinions should more or less coincide. If Winifred chooses to be offended I suppose it cannot be helped, but I am very sorry if such is the case. However, possibly you can straighten things out. I am afraid she will find the pathway to success very hard if she is going to take the remarks made about her work in this way.

Do write me from time to time and tell me how you are. Since I do not know if you are still in Cornwall I am sending Richard’s cheque to his London address, and yours to you at the address you have given me. I wonder how it will be when I go to England and when I can come. Mrs. Russell joins me in much love. You will shortly receive my new book which I hope will be out next week.
